title: volunteer plea for community companions
story: Royal Voluntary Service is looking for volunteers to become Community Companions, a scheme which offers practical support to older people in Inverurie.Tracey Peden, Community Development Operations Manager at Royal Voluntary Service said: “We are initially looking for one or two volunteer coordinators and volunteers to support the scheme in Inverurie, but there is scope to develop the Community Companions service across Aberdeenshire.“Our volunteers find they get as much out of volunteering as they put in it’s incredibly rewarding for them and they make a real dference to the lives of the people they support.“Those who sign up can choose to dedicate as much or as little time to volunteering as they like and full training will be given.”Community Companions volunteers offer the practical help that can make all the dference to older people and help them retain their independence– from assisted shopping and activity programmes, to enabling them to get out and about with community transport. Volunteers also provide company and companionship, while making sure the older person is safe and well.Royal Voluntary Service is one of Britain’s largest volunteering charities with over , volunteers supporting thousands of people each month in hospitals, at home and in the community.To find out more about becoming volunteer call   or email tracey.hann@royalvoluntaryservice.org.uk.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.milngavieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Level Crossing Manager Michael Burnett, Shaun McCabe, PC Derek Jackson and Lauren McCreedy of Network Rail"  Driving voucher win for Inverurie pupil viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: blocking the bus in the hope
story: Police Scotland and Orkney Islands Council are asking drivers to ‘think bus’ when leaving vehicles in St Margaret’s Hope.The X service is frequently prevented from travelling through the village when stationary cars and vans block the narrow entrance to the Back Road from Pier Road and Cromarty Square.“If the bus can’t travel along the Back Road it has to take the new road instead and passengers waiting in the village miss their bus,” said East Mainland, South Ronaldsay and Burray councillor, Steve Sankey.“It’s a growing problem and something bus users and the local community council have raised with me. People expect a reliable service and I can understand their frustration. We’re joining with the Police in asking drivers not to block the way into the Back Road and find somewhere  to park that doesn’t affect the bus.”Chief Inspector Matt Webb, Police Scotland Area Commander for Orkney, said: “We will take actionvehicles are left in ways which restrict the passage of the local bus service.“We would rather not do thatpossible # and I would encourage drivers to be considerate and play their part in making sure buses can move freely through the narrow streets of the village.”If you have any comments or feedback on bus services, please contact the Transportation Team at the Council at transport@orkney.gov.uk or  . title: council issues kirkyards apology
story: Orkney Islands Council has made an official apology following public concern about the way the county#s kirkyards are being managed.Distraught families and dismayed public officials have spoken out in recent weeks, after a scheme to improve the safety of cemeteries triggered reports that headstones were being laid flat without relatives being notied.Last week, a council insider told The Orcadian that — in failing to contact families — the council was disregarding government guidelines on cemetery maintenance.“It says it’s good practice to inform the families and give them an opportunity to repair the memorial, and that’s just not being done at all,” the inside source said.The Orcadian also heard from Stewart Spence, whose father#s headstone had been laid down in the Sandwick kirkyard with no notication from the council. This was despite the fact that the name and address of the person they needed to contact — his mother Edna — was engraved on the memorial.#Vandals couldn#t have done a better job,# he said.Following this wave of public concern, OIC convener Harvey Johnston and chief executive Alistair Buchan have now released a statement apologising for the concern and upset that this project has caused.#Following a tragic accident involving a young child at a Glasgow cemetery, the Scottish Government asked councils to carry out detailed inspections in the interests of public safety,# they said.#We therefore engaged in the kirkyard safety programme for all the right reasons, but recognise that the process we have followed needs to be improved. It was never envisaged that the resulting work would leave kirkyards in the condition they are in. We are sorry about the concern and upset this has led to.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect. We will also consider how best to contact and discuss the remedial work required with those concerned. People’s safety is an important concern for us and we will continue to carry out headstone inspections. As at Warebeth , we will use blue pegs to mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives.#These stones will not be touched until we publicise the inspection results and give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.#The statement also confirmed that further updates from the council will be provided further updates over the weeks ahead.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: featured property of the week 6
story: advertorialFeatured Property of the WeekFebruary ,  at : am##ADVERTORIAL: Price offers over £, The Mound is a well-presented, modern, two double-bedroom, two-storey, end terrace house, located out in the west side of Kirkwall in the Peerie Sea Loan Development. The property is four years old, and has PVC double-glazed windows and doors, air-to-air-source heating, with two  heaters located in the bedrooms.Accommodation on the ground floor comprises a kitchen diner with vinyl flooring and modern units, toilet and under-stairs cupboard, and a carpeted living room with a large window. Stairs from the living room lead to the upstairs landing, bedrooms one and two with built-in wardrobes, and the bathroom with large shower, sink, w.c. and heated towel rail. From the upstairs landing there is access to the loft space, which has been partially floored and light installed.There is a chipped front garden with a path leading to the front door, and a small back garden with grassed and chipped areas, a clothes line and waste area. The air-to-air-source external unit is at the rear of the property.The parking on the development is communal off-street parking. title: german fleet salvage sites archaeology project results published online
story: With the centenary of the scuttling of the German High Seas Fleet in Scapa Flow fast approaching in June of this year, a fascinating insight into remains of aspects of the wrecks has now been published online.Historic Environment Scotland commissioned the Orkney Research Centre for Archaeology and SULA Diving to complete a full survey of the wrecks and debris remaining on the sea bed following the inter-war salvage operations.The seven remaining ships of the High Seas Fleet have seen Scapa Flow become one of the most well-known e sites in the World. Those wrecks are still the primary focus of recreational ers, but the remains of the vessels that were mostly recovered and removed from Scapa Flow have also been a recognised ing resource for many years.However, the exact extent and composition of these so-called salvage sites was unknown until this week, when the report of the second phase of work on these sites was published online.The overall aim of the Scapa Flow Salvage Sites Project was to determine what remains of the many vessels of the German High Seas Fleet that were salvaged in the years that followed their scuttling in June .Phase One, undertaken over the winter of  , involved a side scan sonar survey of the main anchorages and other areas thought to have been involved in the salvage process.In the second phase of this project, ers and remotely operated vehicles examined and recorded the remains in detail.The overall result is that the vast majority of salvage sites in Scapa Flow have been located and the remains at each site have been directly investigated and recorded.The full report is now available for public download through the Scapa Flow Historic Wreck website http:www.scapaflowwrecks projects salvage-sites-phase- Further details in The Orcadian on Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: interactive hie roadshow comes to orkney
story: newsInteractive HIE roadshow comes to OrkneyFebruary ,  at : pm vw, px"  Starting here in Orkney this week, Highlands and Islands Enterprise is hitting the road to teach people how to outsmart online criminals and spot cyber threats.The free Cyber Sense on Tour workshops will visit businesses and communities throughout the Highlands and Islands using fun, interactive games to allow participants to get under the skin of hackers and learn the tricks of the trade.The tour starts in Orkney with two events, the first at Orkney Library this Tuesday, February , and the second at the NorthLink ferry Hamnavoe at the Stromness terminal on Wednesday.The interactive experience is open to all and will use innovative technology to create an immersive ‘point of view’ exercise, were participants can take the role of an employee, a cyber security professional and even a hacker to learn the tricks of the trade.Concepts such as ‘phishing’ will be explained and audiences will be taught to spot scams, dissect spurious emails and prevent hackers taking over their online lives.Working in collaboration with the National Cyber Security Centreand supported by the Scottish Government, the Cyber Sense sessions will provide a memorable and engaging way to discover how everyday actions can help protect people and companies from these evolving cyber dangers.April Conroy, project manager at Highland and Islands Enterprise, said: “As the way we work and live becomes more integrated online, it can be easy to take for granted how much important information we upload to the internet. Whether it’s our personal information on social media or important financial details, it’s vital that we’re aware of how to keep our safe and secure from cyber criminals.”“By really getting under the skin of these hackers, our Cyber Sense workshops can point out how to understand how these iniduals work. Through the games we’ve designed, attendees will be able to competitively play roles on both sides of a cyber-crime. This offers a unique perspective that can show just what preventative measures can be taken to outsmart these online criminals.”To learn more about the Cyber Sense on Tour event and to book a free place, visit www.hellodigital.scot cyber-sense- copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons — Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat — also known as Repulse Bay — in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism — findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians — adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney youth conference takes place
story: Orkney#s biennial Youth Conference, held at the Kirkwall Town Hall yestrday, organised by the OIC#s Community Learning and Development Service, brought together  young people from across Orkney to take part in workshops and hear from keynote speakers on a range of issues.The conference was opened by council Convener Harvey Johnston, who said he was truly delighted and privileged to be at the conference, amongst Orkney#s young people.He continued: #Our young folk are Orkney#s greatest asset and I#m expecting great things from you all. Not just today at this conference, but in your lives to come.#Taking to the stage next was keynote speaker John Loughton. John is a high profile and award winning global youth leader, social entrepreneur, campaigner and leadership speaker. He is founder and CEO of global leadership company DareLead. In  he was elected the youngest ever Chair of the Scottish Youth Parliament.On the back of yesterday#s Orkney Youth Conference, local folk in Orkney who work with children and young people, are gathering today for the third Growing Up in Orkney conference.Today’s conference gives them the opportunity to share and learn from each other as well as find out what’s working well in our communities. It’s also about learning from others and exploring practice further afield and deciding what to stop doing, what we should be doing more of and what we should start doing.Delegates will take part in a range of workshops and hear from keynote speaker Dave Clubb. Dave who hails from Shetland is a Social Worker with  years experience in dferent positions within the Shetland Islands Council before working for five years on a freelance basis and becoming a foster carer. vw, px"  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: power cable repairs completed
story: Repairs to a faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, have been completed and the cable has been put back into use.SSEN have said the cable was put back into service on Sunday evening and has been under normal operation since then.Prior to repairs being completed at Rackwick Bay, Hoy, a spokesman from the energy company said an investigation had shown the damage to be located at a section of the Pentland Firth East cable, near the shore at Rackwick.The spokesman said there was no impact to their customers as a result of the fault and contingency measures were put in place.SSEN also reported that, as part of its subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is at #an advanced stage of development#, with cable installation and commissioning due to take place in autumn next year.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: team appointed for 4 5m north isles landscape partnership scheme
story: The North Isles Landscape Partnership Schemeteam is now up to full strength with the appointment of three new staff members.Anne Bignall, Valerie Dawson, Claire Wilson and programme manager Andy Golightly will work with communities on the North Isles to deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Working with the communities on the North Isles the NILPS will deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, the scheme will support Orkney’s North Isles through the delivery of a number of projects that includes traditional skills training, educational programmes, wildle recording and enhancement of isles heritage centres amongst others.The programme will invest £. million in the North Isles and the project will run until .Mr Golightly said “It’s great to now have the team in place so we can concentrate on delivering the projects in the isles, a lot of work has been done getting to this point and now the focus will be working with the isles communities to start getting things done on the ground.#One of the first things that will be available is the North Isles Landscape Partnership Heritage Grants. Small grants will be available that contribute to the aims and objectives of the NILPS programme. Groups and organisations can apply for grants of up to £ to support projects, activities and events in the isles.Valerie Dawson, NILPS project officer added: “The Heritage Grants are open to applicants now and we would encourage any not for profit organisations, with any ideas related to heritage, that might require funding to contact us to seewe can help.”The project team can be contacted on or email the North Isles Landscape Partnership scheme or visit their website www.nilpscopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Black Isle swimming pool is not yet sunk say supporters
story: DETERMINED campaigners fighting for a swimming pool dedicated to a fast-growing area of Ross-shire have succeeded in a last-ditch bid to keep the dream alive.The Ross-shire Journal last November told how activists behind a -year drive to establish a pool serving the Black Isle issued an appeal to a new generation to either take the plunge and get involved or see it wound up.The Black Isle Swimming Pool Foundationhas raised more than pound, and won planning approval for a new-build in Fortrose next to the existing leisure centre and secondary school.With anumber of BISPF stalwarts no longer able to continue driving the project, chairman Roy Sinclair appealed to Black Islers to grasp the nettle or wind up the foundation.A make-or-break project strategy meeting in Fortrose has seen a fresh commitment to push forward with a number of avenues to be investigated. These include:* A possible community buyout of the Black Isle Leisure Centre run by High Le Highland for Highland Council.* Appointing a business consultant to update the  business plan and probe funding applications.* Appoint a design team by competitive tender to revise the building plans and invite tenders.It was noted that the Black Isle remains a growing area with future housing and an expanding population.While a lottery bid for pound million towards the estimated poundm cost of the scheme failed back in , negotiations with the Scottish Land Fund via Highlands and Islands Enterprise to consider developing the project as a community enterprise company have continued.Mr Sinclair said: "A unanimous positive attitude was evident at the meeting which allows further progress to be made to develop this very important project for the benefit of folk on the Black Isle and beyond."A follow-up meeting is planned later this month.Whats your view  Email newsdesk@spp-groupTuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwall schools delight at 300 donation
story: A SPECIAL school in Dingwall has been the beneficiary of ldquoextraordinary community support after two local women managed to raise hundreds of pounds through a charity raffle.Mhairi Fazekas and Joanne Raeburn staged a Hogmanay raffle run through the Ross-shire Club which generated pound for the school.Around a dozen local businesses offered prizes including the Sports and Model shop, Edinburgh Woollen Mills, Strathpeffer golf club and Peppermint Beauty Salon, among others.Mrs Fazekas said: ldquoWe started selling tickets before Hogmanay and posted it on social media so when people found out it was for St Clements, it helped get people involved.ldquoPeople knowing that it was for St Clements definitely helped because Dingwall is a close-knit community and were more likely to be interested knowing that the money was going there rather than further afield.ldquoCertainly the school was very appreciative because they said it is dficult to raise money at that time of year and the kids were very excited wondering what the money would be spent on.Earlier, Christyna Ferguson whose daughter goes to the school, said the local community had offered the school ldquoextraordinary support over the years.She added: ldquoIt is unbelievable how good the support for St Clements is.ldquoI think people are proud of the school and what it does and want to see it improved.ldquoIt is just unbelievable, I have never seen anything like it.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: MSP issues plea over Ross shire rail reliability
story: RELIABILITY issues and a lack of investment are hampering the rail network in Ross-shirersquos ability to capitalise on growing passenger demand, an MSP has warned.Kate Forbes, who represents Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch, has called for greater investment after annual passenger figures revealed mixed fortunes for some stations amid a general rise in overall use.Passenger numbers at a number of Ross-shire stations have risen in the past year, with the likes of Dingwalland Kyleamong the big winners.But commuter villages like Beauly and Conon Bridge posted drops of around . per cent ndash amid continuing complaints over train cancellations or services failing to stop when attempting to claw back lost time.And campaigners have been pressing for years for the reintroduction of a section of double track at Lentran between Clachnaharry swing bridge and Beauly station to tackle the issue.Ms Forbes said: ldquoPublic transport needs to be reliable, comfortable and regular. title: Parents asked to play their part in dealing with Alness disorder
story: PARENTS in an Easter Ross town are being asked to ensure they know what their children are up to at night following spates of antisocial behaviour which has spurred a fresh police crackdown.Officers say they have spoken to a number of young people in Alness in the presence of their parents following the incidents, which have also prompted an appeal from a local councillor.Police Scotland Easter Ross community policing Inspector Jamie Wilson said: ldquoI would like to thank the local community for their patience whilst we investigate these incidents.ldquoI appreciate that behaviour of this nature is alarming, however I would like to reassure local residents that we are working closely with schools, High Le Highland and partners to reduce and prevent further antisocial behaviour.ldquoWe continue to investigate incidents which have been reported and are following positive lines of enquiry. Those involved will be identied and will either be reported to the procurator fiscal or issued with a Recorded Police Warning as appropriate.ldquoWe will also be issuing parents with antisocial behaviour letters highlighting the conduct of their children in the hope that they may be a positive influence before things escalate.ldquoOver recent weeks we have spoken with several youths regarding their conduct in the presence of their parents. In the main the response has been positive and I would appeal to parents in Alness to support the community by knowing what their children are doing each evening. We will continue to target our resources in the area to address the behaviour of those involved.Backing police action, Councillor Pauline Munrosaid: ldquoThese incidents have caused concern to local residents, particularly where property has been damaged.ldquoI would urge parents to be aware of what their children are up to during the evenings and to discuss where they are going.Nicky Grant, head teacher at Alness Academy, said: ldquoWe are working in partnership with Police Scotland to ensure that our students and parents feel supported, informed and engaged at this time.Anyone with information should contact Police on  or Crimestoppers on  you would prefer to remain anonymous.Back in November, we reported how youth workers in Alness had appealed to people to share concerns with them and also appealed to parents.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Ross shire pupil wins undisclosed sum from Highland Council after wall debris broke leg at school
story: Max MacPhee, aged seven, was injured by falling debris at Ben Wyvis Primary School in Conon Bridge.He was hospitalised with a broken leg and is now left with one leg cm longer than the other.Highland Council denied liability throughout a civil action but last week backtracked by offering an out-of-court settlement after Digby Brown Solicitors proved they knew of an earlier debris fall one year before Max was injured.While glad to win the case, mum Louise MacPhee , accused the council of acting ldquoshamefully.She said: ldquoItrsquos shocking that Highland Council didnrsquot have the common decency to hold their hands up and just help a little boy who was hurt by their own failings instead of having the audacity to try and blame him.Max was injured in May  when he was then aged five-years-old.He had been leaning on the wall after his morning nursery session when a coping stone detached and struck him on the right leg ndash breaking it just beneath the knee.Max spent two months in recovery most of which was spent using a wheelchair or a walking frame.His bed was placed in the living room as he couldnrsquot walk up the stairs and for the first few weeks of his recovery the youngster also had to be bathed by hand while lying on top of the kitchen counter because he couldnrsquot get in the bath.Louise, a bar maid from Conon Bridge, added: ldquoThe council put us through hell, not to mention wasted public money on legal bills, when they could just have done the right thing from day one.ldquoAt least now they can be held accountable and everyone will know their shameful tactics in blaming a little boy.ldquoIf therersquos any good to come from this then I hope itrsquos that the council give themselves a serious shake and invest in improving the safety of public areas so people arenrsquot hurt in the first place.David McGowan, associate at Digby Brownrsquos Inverness office, led the legal action against Highland Council.He said his investigations found the local authority was alerted to structure concerns at Ben Wyvis Primary when a coping stone fell from the same wall in .But despite this he claimed the council failed to carry out adequate inspections or repair work.Mr McGowan, who helped secure the undisclosed settlement, said: ldquoThis was clearly an accident waiting to happen and itrsquos distressing to consider how much worse Max or anyone  could have been injured.ldquoEvery local authority has a duty of care towards those entering their premises and this is especially important when considering schools and nurseries.ldquoSecuring rightful damages is just one aspect of how we help iniduals - the other is holding defenders accountable to hopefully improve safety standards for all.Asked for comment, a Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoIt is the councilrsquos policy not to comment on insurance claims.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Unclaimed bikes find new home at Alness Academy
story: UNCLAIMED bicycles have been donated by Police Scotland to a Ross-shire school.The bikes, which have been handed over to Alness Academy, will be used in the schoolrsquos bicycle maintenance programme.Sergeant Calum Reid, of the Alness community policing team, told the Journal: ldquoWe were delighted to donate these bikes to Alness Academy and we are always keen to support the work of the Alness Youth Partnership.The eight bikes had been in long-term storage at Alness police station but never recovered by their owners.Sgt Reid gave them away after hearing about the initiative.He said: ldquoIrsquom sure they will now be put to very good use, teaching young people valuable skills for the future.The bike maintenance scheme is run by the schoolrsquos craft, design and technology department, which teaches pupils how to repair, strip and carry out general maintenance on bikes.The programme is more than just an after-school club to the pupils as they receive a SQA level  qualication after completing the course.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Wester Ross island dream moves a step closer to reality
story: AMBITIOUS plans to transform a remote island off the coast of Wester Ross into a world class visitor destination have moved a step closer.Summer Isles Enterprise have lodged a planning application with Highland Council to rebuild a derelict croft house at the Ardnagoine settlement on Tanera Mor.The island was bought in  by English businessman Ian Wace and his we Saffron for pound million and the couple have embarked on a four-year plan to transform it into a retreat for up to  paying guests.Former co-owner of Tanera, Lizzie Williams, who is working with the new owners to realise their dream, said five properties on the island were now occupied by members of a team working on buildings on the island.The latest plans are to restore and convert the croft into a two-bedroom dwelling linked by a conservatory. The site overlooks Badentarbet Bay and the two ruins appear to have originally been one long building.In the consultation documents, agents Reynolds Architecture say the design of the building has involved historical research and where possible, reclaimed materials will be used in the construction work.An access track to the south of the dwelling would allow access to the site.This is the sixth property to be restored on the island which once had a population of .The intention is to rebuild the settlements of Ardnagoine, Tigh-an-Quay an Garadheancal to create three distinct clusters which will allow for three dferent groups of guests to occupy the island at any one time, or for one large party to take over the entire island.As well as providing jobs in the reconstruction of the ruins on the island, there will be long-term employment for local people servicing and maintaining the facilities.ldquoWe have already carried out work on the quarry cottage, the byre, the kitchen croft and a cafe pub by the shore and Mathesons, another ruin, has been converted into a cottage, ldquo said Ms Williams.ldquoWe bring tradesmen and other workers over from Achiltibuie and Ullapool on a daily basis and workers who travel from further afield stay on the island and go home at weekends.ldquoWe are looking to restore up to another  properties on the island.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Winning efforts in Highland Hospcie competition
story: YOUNG business brains from across the Highlands were put to the test in a competition which sharpened their entrepreneurial skills and raised money for a deserving cause.Teams of six from local schools competed in the event organised by Highland Hospice.Secondary school pupils took each other on for the Young Highland Apprentice title, while primary children battled it out in their own junior event.The aim in both cases was to come up with a new product or service that could be sold to raise funds for the hospice.Pupils from Lochardil Primary School in Inverness triumphed in the junior category for their Rocks and Crosses game, a version of noughts and crosses using hand-painted rocks which comes with a gt bag that doubles up as the game board.Sales raised a total of pound. and saw the school crowned winners after a presentation at Inverness College UHI this week.Judges said they were impressed with their business acumen as well as their knowledge of the hospice and the work it does.Winning pound for their school courtesy of event sponsors Tailormade Moves, teacher Muriel Murray said: ldquoTheyrsquore delighted, really proud of themselves.ldquoItrsquos good to see their hard work recognised.In the older age category it was a team from Fortrose Academy who were triumphant, and Tain Royal Academy were runners-up.A team of fth years ran a whole iety of fundraising events between September and January that allowed them to present the hospice with a cheque for pound..Speaking about the impact of the competition as a whole, hospice community fundraiser Katie Gibb said: ldquoAs Highland Hospice is a vital service for the whole of the Highland community, this is a great way for us to raise awareness about our services within the younger generation.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: uk is world s 5th richest country but it s far from fair christine jardine
story: Every child should have the opportunity to fulfill their potential and it#s up to those of us who have managed to do that to make sure it happens, writes Christine Jardine.There is a childhood Christmas that I view very dferently now than I did then.Santa had brought me a bike. It was a beautul thing and I cherished it for years. But I remember one of the strange things about that Christmas was going back to school.It must have been primary  or , and we had a group discussion in class about what Santa had brought us all.At the time, I wondered why so many of my classmates had asked for what I innocently termed “boring” things, like a new coat.Years later however, when Christmas began to bite into my own budget, I realised that my child’s vision of the world had not seen the real signicance of the gts.I do not come from a particularly well-off background.For the first decade and a half of my le we lived in a house rented from the housing association.We didn’t have a lot but I had both a new coat and a bike that year.I’m not sure but I think that memory had a lot to do with my recent determination to be my party’s spokesperson on the Department of Work and Pensions .Oh some witty person – probably one of my sisters – will say it’s more to do with me getting closer to my pension.But as any WASPI woman will tell you, that’s not as close as it used to be, which is an argument for another day.No. Every week constituents come to me who have been given what can best be termed as “the run around” by some section of the DWP.: Amber Rudd: Families on universal credit did have to use food banksIt could be pensions, it could be Universal Credit or it could be the system of Personal Independence Payments for those with a disability which, as assessment systems go, is not fit for purpose.In every one of them, I see someone who deserves to be treated better.In each case I’m reminded that in this, the fth richest nation on earth, there are still people for whom le is a daily economic challenge.And what we often overlook is that the majority of those who find themselves facing an uphill financial struggle are already working for a living – the ‘just about managing’ to whom Theresa May promised so much in her first speech as Prime Minister.In a meeting this week with the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, I was stunned to hear that of the already unacceptable number of children living in poverty in this country, two-thirds are from working households.How are we getting it so wrong in this country I have written in this newspaper before about my frustrations at the problem in our country’s welfare system, of which we were once so proud.I have criticised the management of the changes in state pension age for women.And I have railed at the issues with the well-intentioned but fatally underfunded Universal Credit.Only this week the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, Amber Rudd, admitted that its failings have been responsible for sending so many people to food banks.But the crux of my gripe is that I realise that we have slipped very far from the fair society, backed by a strong economy, we aim to be.: Rudd urged to ditch DWP policies after damning UN reportOne half of that, the former, we have managed to achieve. The other still seems to be tantalisingly out of our reach. And it needn’t be.I am not in Government. ButI were, the first thing I would do in my new post would be to act on that recognition which Amber Rudd is the first in the Cabinet to publicly acknowledge.I would put back the £ billion which George Osborne took out of the budget for Universal Credit.Then I would pause the roll-out and migration from legacy benefits and fix the obvious problems that are leaving families with nothing to live on for more than a month, causing people to fall into rent arrears and adding stress to an already intolerable burden.After that, I would address the issues which still allow situations where the benefits of getting a job are undermined.But, more than anything , I would want to do something about those children in poverty.I thought about them this week and I thought about that Christmas when I was no more than eight or nine years old.At that time, le was simple for me.I had a big loving family and any financial challenges my parents might have faced were well hidden from us.For my younger sisters, it was slightly dferent.When my dad died at the age of , we went overnight from being relatively well off and living in a home we owned to a single-parent family with no income. My mum went back out to work and somehow managed to give my sisters everything I had known.But, at the age of , I realised how easy it is to fall through the cracks.Then, like now, I thought about those kids in my class that Christmas.Most of them had at least as much potential as I did, but not all of them got to fulfill it.Today that thought as much as,not more than, any political principle I have is what drives my daily le. I have been lucky. I have been able to give my daughter the start in le my parents were able to give me.Maybe because of that I want every child to have the opportunity to fulfill their potential, and feel it’s up to those of us who have to make sure it happens.No family should have to choose between Christmas presents and keeping warm.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: nicola sturgeon eu nationals crucial to scotland s well being
story: Nicola Sturgeon will say EU nationals at #crucial# to Scotland#s well-being as she appears before delegates in the French Parliament today.Scotland’s First Minister will appear before the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Assemblée Nationale, the lower house of the French legislature in Paris.The SNP leader will attack theUK’s decision to end Freedom of Movement as part of its Brexit deal as a ‘self-defeating measure’ and pledge to give her support to EU citizens currently living in Scotland. - Scottish students warned off taking music as a subject to save schools money“Those EU citizens of course include , French people, who are our colleagues, friends, neighbours and in many cases our family. The Scottish Government is proud that they have done us the honour of making Scotland their home,” is expected to tell teh delegates.“We will always stick up for their rights - in recent months we have lobbied successfully to ensure EU citizens would not have to pay a fee to obtain settled status in the UK. “And we will always make it clear that EU citizens are welcome. In fact in the coming months, we plan to step up our efforts to encourage EU citizens to stay in Scotland.”She was invited to address the -strong Foreign Affairs Committee by Marielle de Sarnez, the chair of the committee and former French Minister for European Affairs.Ms Sturgeon’s is visiting the French capital to boost trade links and will also open the Scottish Government’s new office in the city today. The impact of Brexit is likely to be damaging and long-lasting, the SNP leader will say.“For me, this is one of the saddest parts of Brexit,” she will add. - Early medical care could have saved the le of Scottish actor’s daughter“The UK Government is proclaiming the end of free movement as a victory – instead, it is a self-defeating measure. It removes opportunity from millions of people. “It is an approach which is especially damaging to Scotland. Without freedom of movement there is a danger that our population will start to decline. We could face workforce shortages in rural areas, in our universities, in our care and health services. European nationals are not only very welcome in Scotland. They are crucial to our well-being.”The SNP is opposing the the deal which Theresa May struck with EU leaders who are refusing to renegotiate and Ms Sturgeon will also hit out at the “red lines” set out by the UK Prime Minister.“Given the existence of those red lines, I understand why the European Union believes that the deal agreed in November is the best which could be achieved,” Ms Sturgeon will add.“And I appreciate that many people in France and across the EU would like the UK to just get on with it.“But no government of Scotland which has the interests of this and future generations at heart could possibly support the current deal.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: sick of jeremy corbyn and sick of politics as usual labour mps walk out
story: Jeremy Corbyn has been warned he faces more resignations after a group of Labour MPs broke away from the party, calling on others to follow them and reshape British politics.In the biggest party schism since the s, seven MPs quit yesterday in protest at Mr Corbyn’s leadership, accusing him of allowing Labour to become “institutionally antisemitic” and claiming a Corbyn government would “threaten our national security”.The Labour deputy leader and the party’s most senior Scottish MP led warnings that more walkouts would follow unless Mr Corbyn did more to embrace his critics and tackle a culture of harassment and bullying. MPs Luciana Berger, Chris Leslie, Gavin Shuker, Mike Gapes, Angela Smith, Ann Coffey and Chuka Umunna wrote to party officials informing them of their resignation moments before holding a press conference to reveal their plans.They appealed to others angry at the deadlock over Brexit and the looming risk of a no-deal exit from the EU to quit their parties and join a new “Independent Group” in the centre ground.Mr Corbyn said he was “disappointed” by the announcement. Shadow chancellor John McDonnell challenged the seven to resign from Parliament and fight by-elections under their new independent banner.But in a stark message from Mr Corbyn’s deputy, Tom Watson said he “feared this day would come” and warned that “unless we change, we may see more days like this”.Mr Watson criticised the handling of antisemitism allegations and said Ms Berger had fallen victim to “a virulent form of identity politics that has seized the Labour Party”.He called for an immediate reshuffle of the frontbench team to reflect dfering opinions in the parliamentary Labour Party.Struggling to contain their emotion, the seven MPs condemned the direction of their former party since Mr Corbyn took office. Ms Berger, who has faced death threats over her criticism of the Labour leadership, said she had become “embarrassed and ashamed” of representing a party she claimed was “institutionally antisemitic”.Mr Leslie said Labour had been “hijacked by the machine politics of the hard left” and claimed Mr Corbyn’s hostility to business and Nato flowed from a “narrow, outdated ideology”.Mr Umunna encouraged members of all parties angry at the conduct of politics to support their group. Established parties “can’t provide the change because they have become the problem”, Mr Umunna said. He added: “If you are sick and tired of politics as usual, guess what  So are we.“If you want an alternative, please help us build it. The bottom line is this – politics is broken. It doesn’t have to be this way. Let’s change it.”Responding to the resignations, Mr Corbyn said: “I am disappointed that these MPs have felt unable to continue to work together for the Labour policies that inspired millions at the last election and saw us increase our vote by the largest share since .”There were contrasting responses from Labour’s union backers. Unison general secretary Dave Prentis said the party had to “look long and hard at the reasons why the MPs feel they are no longer able to stay”.But Unite general secretary Len McCluskey – one of the key powers behind Mr Corbyn’s leadership – accused the breakaway MPs of “hypocrisy” for standing for election on a Labour manesto.“All of them got massive increases in their majorities,” he said. “It wasn’t because of their own personal charisma. It was because of the manesto, which promised to respect the  referendum.”Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable said he was “open to working with like-minded groups and iniduals” to bring about a second EU referendum and would seek talks with the members of the Independent Group.The SNP’s Westminster leader Ian Blackford said the split in Labour showed Westminster was “now completely dysal”.He said: “Labour are not fit for purpose – they are failing as an opposition, failing over Brexit and failing their own MPs.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: scottish primary pupil wins settlement after he was crushed by a wall
story: A primary school pupil who was crushed by a wall leaving him with a broken leg that is now a centimetre longer than the other has won an out-of-court settlement.Max MacPhee was five years old when a wall he was leaning on collapsed in the playground at Ben Wyvis Primary School in Conon Bridge, near Dingwall, in the Highlands.He had been leaning on the wall after his morning nursery session when a coping stone detached and struck him on the right leg, breaking it just beneath the knee.Max spent two months recovering, most of which was spent using a wheelchair or a walking frame. His bed was placed in the living room as he could not walk up the stairs.For the first few weeks of his recovery the youngster also had to be bathed by hand while lying on top of a kitchen worktop because he could not get into a bath.Max, now aged seven, has been left with one leg cm shorter than the other and his family sued Highland Council, which initially denied liability.Investigations by law firm Digby Brown found the local authority was alerted to structure concerns at Ben Wyvis Primary when a coping stone fell from the same wall in  - a year before Max was injured. Despite this, the council still failed to carry out adequate inspections or repair work.Max’s mother Louise MacPhee, , said the Highland Council “tried to blame” her son.She said: “It’s shocking that Highland Council didn’t have the common decency to hold their hands up and just help a little boy who was hurt by their own failings instead of having the audacity to try and blame him. The council put us through hell, not to mention wasted public money on legal bills, when they could just have done the right thing from day one. At least now they can be held accountable and everyone will know their shameful tactics in blaming a little boy.”Highland Council denied liability throughout a civil action but last week backtracked by offering an out-of-court settlement.David McGowan, who helped to secure the settlement, said: “This was clearly an accident waiting to happen and it’s distressing to consider how much worse Max or anyone  could have been injured.“Every local authority has a duty of care towards those entering their premises.”The sum of the settlement has not been disclosed.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

A animal skin cloak completes the look. the suit was very warm, a blessing on a day like today.If the breastplate is simple that is in contrast to the fierce-looking helmets which are designed to look like a dragon#s head, complete with #scales# hanging from the back of the helmets.Squad member Lynden Nicolson has spent hours working on the helmets and said he was thrilled with the way they had turned out. The axes are special too with the axe head crafted out of Damascus steel.Mr Nicolson was looking forward to the day ahead, saying: #It is brilliant to get here today and see everybody together. story: A DIVE vessel with  women on board was escorted into port after she began taking in water off Shetland on Sunday. issued a mayday call in bad weather soon after midday when she was approximately eight miles east of Sumburgh Head. The wooden boat was taking in water in rough seas in the Roost. into Lerwick harbour.Shetland Coastguard watch officer Alex Dodge said: “The  on board were all safe and well. The skipper handled the situation extremely well.”The -year-old converted fishing boat, with an all-female crew and female passengers, was heading to Shetland for a ing trip, and will be in the isles for the next few weeks. since January last year and has  years experience as a power boat instructor, said she called the coastguard as a precaution. was [originally] a fishing boat and well able for the conditions.”The problem started when the boat began taking in water from the rudder gland and a deck hatch, she said. title: earlston folk get resilient
story: Earlston#s resilience team, recently formed as part of the town#s Community Action Plan, received a breath of fresh air in its second session. Tweed Valley Mountain Rescue volunteers led training in emergency resuscitation .At the group’s next meeting, on Thursday, February , its hoped to build on their new knowledge by learning about defibrillators, supporting the recent introduction of equipment into the town.The initial set-up of the resilience team is supported by emergency planning at Scottish Borders Council, which organises training and provides equipment which will be kept in a central, locked storage facility. Business owner Ritchie Grierson, of the Red Lion, has agreed to provide this space.Community councillor and local coordinator Norman Catto, said: “Emergency support teams are very successful where in the Borders and we would hope to support our community whenever called to by the emergency services or the council.”Mr Catto said although there has been a good take-up of places in the group, there is no upper limit and more people were more than welcome to join up.He said: “It’s great that more than  volunteers have already come forward, but we can never have too many. Everyone is very welcome to the next meeting to learn more and sign up.”z Pictured is a CPR demonstration at the latest meeting.
